p: Moreover, how do such genetic patterns translate to antigenic properties, that is, viral interaction with anti-HA antibodies? In 2004, new techniques allowed a characterization of the antigenic evolution of the influenza subtype H3N2 [ 74] during the years since its introduction into humans in 1968. The resulting pattern is characterized by “punctuations” in antigenic evolution, occurring roughly every 2–8 years, in contrast with the more gradual pattern of genetic change shown in Fig. 5.9a. These punctuations have great importance for public health, often necessitating major reformulation of current, HA-based vaccines [ 81].
